poem:
**Drips and Floods**

In the chamber's echo, compliments flow,  
like rain drops on a window, words drip  
from backbench lips. A statesman, they say,  
to unite the divide, to douse the fire  
that roars afar. Yet, cuts can carve  
a rift more wide, dissent in silence  
brews its storm, a flood eager to rise.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "More benefit cuts would risk turning drops of dissent in Labour’s ranks into a flood | Isabel Hardman There was a telling moment at prime minister’s questions last week when a super-keen Labour backbencher used his moment in the spotlight to praise Keir Starmer as a “true statesman”. Mike Tapp was dripping with compliments for his boss as he argued that the Commons should be “united” in order to “achieve a lasting peace” in Ukraine.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
